title: 103_s1249
content: The Act may be cited as the "Tuberculosis Prevention and Control Amendments of 1993". Between 10,000,000 and 15,000,000 people in the United States have been infected with tuberculosis, with nearly 26,000 new cases reported annually, resulting in over 1,700 deaths each year. The number of reported cases has increased from 22,201 in 1985 to 26,673 in 1992. Drug-resistant tuberculosis strains can be costly to treat, with a high mortality rate despite treatment efforts. In 1992, tuberculosis cases were reported in all 50 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention. In 1992, tuberculosis cases were reported in all 50 states to the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention, with cases resistant to one or more drugs reported in at least 36 states, the District of Columbia, and Puerto Rico. 27 percent of reported cases occurred in foreign-born persons, and tuberculosis remains the number one killer among infectious diseases worldwide, with 8,000,000 new cases and 2,900,000 deaths annually. SEC. 3. PROGRAMS OF CENTERS FOR DISEASE CONTROL AND PREVENTION. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act includes increased funding for tuberculosis prevention and control services for fiscal years 1994 through 1997. States applying for grants must demonstrate a plan for ensuring the provision of tuberculosis services. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act requires states to demonstrate plans for providing tuberculosis services to high-risk populations or areas with high infection rates. Grant funds must be used for effective interventions and therapy for those with active tuberculosis infections. The amendment to the Public Health Service Act allows the Secretary to conduct research and training on tuberculosis prevention, control, and treatment. $26,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 1994 for this purpose. The amendment authorizes $26,000,000 for fiscal year 1994 and additional funds for the following years to support research and training on tuberculosis prevention, control, and treatment. A technical amendment removes a sentence from the Public Health Service Act. The amendment authorizes funding for research and training on tuberculosis prevention, control, and treatment through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. The amendment authorizes $46,000,000 for research on tuberculosis through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases. The amendment authorizes $46,000,000 for research on tuberculosis through the National Institute of Allergy and Infectious Diseases for fiscal year 1994, with additional funding for the following years. The Food and Drug Administration will implement a tuberculosis drug and device research program with a $5,000,000 annual budget. This program includes assisting other agencies in developing tuberculosis protocols, reviewing medical devices for tuberculosis diagnosis, and conducting research on drugs and devices for tuberculosis control.
